text:
LIZ: So Anand is SVP
of Product at Rula. He's been involved in product
management for 10-plus years

and has led teams of product
managers at Gusto, Dropbox, and Zynga. He's a Stanford alum and teaches
product management courses

on campus at Stanford and in
our online product management program as well.

And Mike is a professor of civil
and environmental engineering and a senior fellow at the Woods
Institute for the Environment.

He is the academic director
for our product management and advanced product
management programs

and teaches them some
of the courses as well. And now I'll hand things
off to Mike and Anand.

MICHAEL LEPECH:
Thanks so much, Liz. And along with Liz, I
want to welcome everyone

to this webinar. As Liz had alluded to,
in the Q&A session,

please put your
questions in there. Try to keep them
reasonably general so that everyone can
learn from the discussion.

But I know that Anand
and I are really excited to see some
questions come in,

and we'll be keeping
an eye on the Q&A box

throughout the entire webinar. So it's great. Wonderful to see
you again, Anand.

ANAND SUBRAMANI: Pleasure. Thank you for having me, Mike. MICHAEL LEPECH: So, the
title of this webinar--

[LAUGHS] ANAND SUBRAMANI:
Intentionally provocative. MICHAEL LEPECH:
Intentionally provocative. And it feels like many
of a series of webinars

or a series of things that have
happened throughout Silicon Valley history, it seems, where
one thing, is declared dead,

and then it comes back. And then we move in these
cycles of ups and downs

as it relates to Silicon Valley
and the economy more generally. So why do you think people
are saying that product
management is dead? ANAND SUBRAMANI: Sure.

I'll give a couple
of different reasons that I think are probably
worth going into. The catalyst, I think,
for a lot of this

originally was, maybe
a few years ago, Brian Chesky, who's one
of the founders of Airbnb,

got up on stage, I believe,
during a design conference and said, Airbnb is eliminating
the role of traditional product

managers. And everybody clapped
and said, great work. He was like, hold on. That's not actually
what that means. And everyone kind of
forgot the last part.

So I think that was the catalyst
for some of the discussion. But in terms of why some
people are celebrating it,

why some people are
saying this is happening, my take is, I think
there's actually two things going on under the
hood that are pretty different.

And one is a little bit older,
and one is a little bit newer. The older one is, I
think a lot of companies

don't have great product
management functions. And if you don't have a good
product management function,

it is often more helpful to have
less product management rather than more product management. We can talk about some
of the pitfalls here.

But the classic thing that
I've seen in organizations is confusing product management
and project management.

And when you have way too
many project managers, that tends to be
counterproductive. I think that's
certainly one reason.

To some extent, some people
are rooting for the function to fail. And then I think the other
one, which is much newer,

is AI is changing
some of the way that product management
work happens. And I know we have some
questions we can go through

in a few minutes. But those are, I think,
the two primary drivers of why this conversation is
happening in the first place,

and happy to zoom in
more on either one. MICHAEL LEPECH: Yeah, that
comment that you had just

made about the fact that the
role of product management gets confused often
with other roles,

like project management, in
companies, is one of the reasons that I think that
we're seeing this

and that the clearly
defined role. Because it is such a
blurry role on the edges

and what the responsibility set
is, it can make it seem like, oh, we don't need it anymore,
and it would be declared dead.

But I think the
differentiation that I make whenever we introduce the
overall program is that project

management is all about
resource allocation and knowing a defined series of
steps to get the project done.

And normally, we know
that sequence of steps prior to the project starting.

And the classic example
is a construction project, where you're going to start with
the foundation and build up.

It doesn't mean it's
easy, but it is known, whereas product management
is a completely different set

of skills. And that's why I
personally think it's still very much alive and necessary.

ANAND SUBRAMANI: I
100% agree with that. I guess I have a
vested interest. You're a little bit
more of a neutral party, but I very much think
it is still alive.

And I actually think it's
going to become probably more important over the
next five years. So I might have a
contrarian take here,

but we can talk
about why I think the importance is increasing. The short answer is, I
think there's probably never been an easier time to
create software or do

design using a bunch of tools. And actually, the skill is
knowing what people want. So that's the thing I'm long on
versus being a junior engineer,

for example. MICHAEL LEPECH: Yeah, no, I
think that's exactly right.

Do you see the title changing? Do you see the function
changing as we move forward?

Or is it just simply,
look, this has been said, but it's not really true?

ANAND SUBRAMANI:
I've seen one way in which I think
the function has changed in a general purpose. And then the second is a
little more company-specific.

I'm seeing a bit of
a merging of product managers and general managers. That certainly has
always been true.

But historically,
sometimes there were general managers that
had PMs reporting to them. Sometimes the PMs had
GMs reporting to them.

I'm seeing a little bit
of a consolidation here. And for what it's
worth, I don't think this is a change in any
of the responsibilities.

For the most part, once you are
called a director at a product management, you are effectively
doing a general manager function

as well. But I'm thinking some of
those titles changing, so more common in
the past few years are things like head of
product/general manager, which

you probably didn't
really see five years ago. But it isn't changing the
work on a day-to-day basis. It's still the same thing.

To answer the other
part of your question about the
company-specific stuff,

so you mentioned the
product management is pretty heterogeneous,
and I agree with that. And one way of
thinking about it is,

you fill in the white space
of whatever that company is inherently bad at. So if you work at
a place like Apple,

where you have a very
strong design function, your product managers
tend to do less design, and they tend to do
more project management.

If you work at a
place like Google, where you have a very
strong engineering function, and your
product managers might do more of a
customer-facing thing,

same at Amazon. So the product manager
role, while you all have the same name, it's
tweaked pretty strongly

based on what the
company is really good at and what its core
DNA looks like. And in some of those
places, I'm seeing

it getting merged more with
customer-facing functions, which I think is good. So product marketing
and product management

are becoming a little bit
closer together in some places. And I view it as mostly
getting closer to the customer being a good thing.

MICHAEL LEPECH: I
think that's right. In particular, as we see
the role and the function

maturing over time, we start
to see a redefinition of titles

within product management,
because necessarily, you are going to get more senior
folks within the function

and they have to carry different
titles than everyone just being a product manager.

So this is of a natural
progression of the maturity of the function.

ANAND SUBRAMANI: For sure. And I think one other
thing that comes to mind, which I've seen
more and more of, which was quite
rare five years ago,

is I'm now seeing C-level
representation more commonly, like chief product officers.

And actually more commonly,
I'm seeing engineering rolling into those people. Where previously, it was pretty
standard to have a CTO and maybe

a VP of product, it's much more
common now to just have a CPO, and actually engineering
function reports in.

And part of this is based
on what drives the company. But for a lot of companies where
if you're building generic SaaS

software and the
engineering is not trivial, but it's not a
complicated thing, right? A lot of people in the
world have figured out

how to build SaaS software,
where you're trying to do is consolidate the
engineering function, the product management
more closely,

and recognize that the thing
that gives the company magic is the product function. So let's tie engineering
more closely to it.

MICHAEL LEPECH:
Yeah, and, of course, that organizational change is--

it creates its own
interesting challenges. We'll talk about those. And actually, in
some of the courses

we teach on leadership
of the product function, we specifically talk about
how you want to bring together

all of those functionalities
and how, as a product person, you can oversee and lead teams
of those varied skill sets

and talents. I think this is a
great transition into trying to understand,
OK, if it's not dead,

how really has it changed? And specifically,
how do you think the role has changed in tech
and also other industries?

Because yes, here obviously
we're very tech-focused. But product has a role
in lots of industries.

ANAND SUBRAMANI: Sure. Let me start actually
maybe with non-tech. I have seen in my teaching
a lot of non-tech companies

sending some of their people to
learn product management basics. And I mostly think
that's a good thing.

We're talking sort of legacy
telecom companies, construction companies-- I teach a class in the
Graduate School of Engineering,

civil engineering
department and cross-listed in management science. We take people
from every school. We have people from the school
of medicine, the school of law.

We have people from the
school of education. So I think there's broadly an
awareness of product management

as a tool for solving problems. And I'm seeing more
and more people, if not taking the actual title,
at least developing the skill.

I've seen product
managers at nonprofits, which I never saw 10 years ago. So to answer the second
part of your question,

I think outside of
technology, there's a broad interest
in figuring out how to bring these skills
into the company and get closer to the customer
to build more things that people

want. I view that very
much as a good thing. Inside of tech, I think it's a
little bit more of a mixed bag.

And the reason I say that is we
talk about product management sort of filling
in the white space in a lot of these companies.

And I think one of the places
where people are frustrated with product management
is where they're trying to fill in the white
space on strategy gaps.

But it turns out that an L2
product manager cannot fill in the white space
on strategy gaps,

so you end up with a bunch
of product managers who are effectively routers to different
parts of the organization.

But really, this is an
organizational failing. It's not a product
management failing. So this is actually
what happened at Airbnb.

Some friends who were
there at the time. And I reached out to them. And they made an announcement
like, no, no, no, it's not

that the function is failing. It's that it turns
out that there are too many small
individual teams, there's too much
coordination overhead.

But the reason that's
true is because we don't have a strong enough
directive around what we should be doing from a
strategy perspective.

So we are going to be much
more tops-down than we were bottoms-up in the past. And that's the reason we're
doing this consolidation.

But product management,
to some extent, is incidental to that problem. It's a company strategy problem. So I'm certainly
seeing more of that

as tech companies get bigger
and a little bit more bloated.

MICHAEL LEPECH: As we think
about outside of Silicon Valley, I loved your comment about--

in our product
management classes here, we're getting students
from across the university. And I think that this
mindset of everyone

has a product because everyone
has a user or a customer to some extent, broadening your
viewpoint on what it is that you

provide to others,
whether it's a solution, whether it's software,
simply whether it's a way

to help them do their job. Viewing other people as
the users of your output is a helpful way to think about
connecting to other people,

both in your organization
and other organizations. And so it's not necessarily
that you have to have a product

that you're looking to launch
and develop and get out there. Rather, it's a way of
thinking about interactions

with other people who
need your work product. And I find that's so powerful. ANAND SUBRAMANI:
100% agree with that.

Another way of
expressing this is it's just empathetic problem-solving. And everybody's doing that
no matter where you work.

MICHAEL LEPECH: Yeah. Yep, absolutely. So there are lots of
different methodologies

that we hear on a regular basis
getting introduced, whether it's Agile or sitting in front of
a Jira board or Confluence

or whatever else it is. And how do you see these having
affected a structured product

management function? And do tools like that make
the role of the product manager

unimportant? ANAND SUBRAMANI: Sure. I think they've mostly
negatively affected the function

because it confuses people what
the function is supposed to do. Drawing a construction
analogy, if your job

was to build a
house, you spend all of your time arguing about
what's the best hammer, you've kind of lost the plot. The point is to build the house.

So in terms of
methodology, whether it's Waterfall or Agile or Jira
or Confluence or Linear, pick any tool of
your choice, these

are project management details. And like we talked
about earlier, they're not really product
management details.

I'm not saying product
managers can totally abscond their project management
responsibility, absolutely not. You have to do some
of it, and the company

needs to be good at it as well. But I see a lot of mid-career
PMs here get very confused.

They spend a bunch of their
time like, how do I Confluence harder or how do I Jira harder? And I'm like, it's
kind of not the point.

Sure, it's helpful to be
proficient at the tools, but the thing that's
going to get you and your company
to the next level is not being better at Jira.

It's being better at
understanding your customers and figuring out the
right thing to build. So I mostly view the dialogue
around the project management

methodologies and the
project management tools as a little bit of
missing the point. I'm not saying the
value is zero at all.

It's worth being
good at those things. But it's way better spending
the time talking about, who is our customer? What do they care about?

How do we generate
value for them? And just talk about how
you do your tickets. MICHAEL LEPECH: Yeah. Yeah.

The analogy that I would make,
going back to the construction analogy, is like, you can have
the greatest Gantt chart showing

how every single one of
those steps is created, and yet, at the end
of the day, no one wants to buy a Gantt chart.

ANAND SUBRAMANI: You put the
house in the wrong place. And you're like, well, it
didn't matter what you did. So this is the thing I
feel very strongly about.

My organizations, I actually
push as much project management as possible out of
the product function

and generally into the
engineering function. And the reason for that
is it makes it very clear what the job is. The job of the product
manager is to figure out,

who is our customer? What problem are we
solving for them? Why is it important, and
how will we create value?

Is it the intersection of things
that the customer cares about and the company cares about? And everything else is details.

MICHAEL LEPECH: Yeah. This actually builds right off
the question that just came in from Michael, saying
like, look, we're

20 years into the idea of
product management being a role. And people still confuse this.

What is it going to
take for them to get it? And if I can provide my
somewhat biased feedback on that

or answer to that one, it is
very much a standardization

of what the job entails. And this was in part why we
created the program of product

management here at
Stanford to have a very clear definition of
this is what the job entails.

Yes, of course it has
other pieces to it, but there is a set of jargon. There is a set of nomenclature
and a set of practices

that if applied across,
really do define the function and the role
in ways that you can start

to push back on, this is
my job, this is what I do, and this is the value
I bring to the company.

But what do you think? What is it going to take
for people to understand what a product manager does? ANAND SUBRAMANI: I agree
with everything you said,

but I think the problem that
is trickier and a bit more insidious to solve is it
requires sharing control.

And the reason for that is,
for better or for worse, a lot of companies tend to be
quite hierarchical, very rigid

and strong preference
for top-down organization versus bottom-up organization.

There are certainly exceptions. But in most places, the people
at the top of the organization are the people who spend the
least time talking to customers.

So what you want is you
want distributed control amongst large portions
of the organization.

You have clear mission. You have clear strategy. And the PMs can be responsible
for actually figuring out

what you should build. But if you don't give them
any autonomy or any agency to actually figure out
a roadmap, for example,

then you've forced it
into a project management. You've collapsed all of
the other possibilities. So to some extent,
you have to be

interested in changing
what you're actually working on as an output
of changing the function. If you're not, then it's
not going to go anywhere.

MICHAEL LEPECH: Yeah. No, absolutely, absolutely. Lightning question here,
what project management tool

do you specifically like? Not trying to advertise anyone,
but is there one that you like? ANAND SUBRAMANI:
I've used a bunch--
I've used a bunch of them. I've used Trello. I've used Jira. I've used Linear.

I've used others. And my actual take on this
is it doesn't really matter.

Pick anything you want,
anything your company is happy with,
anything that works. I've used Asana. Again, I've used
probably a dozen of these

in different shapes and forms. And my actual take is
they're all pretty similar. Pick anything you want.

If someone in your
team is really passionate about configuring
Jira for you, great. Have at it.

Have a nice time. Have a nice time. But I usually leave this
up to the engineering

function to pick because
they're going to be the people-- certainly, the product managers
spend their time in Jira. But they will spend more
of their time in it.

So I'm mostly a little
[INAUDIBLE] engineering function, if you're very happy
with project management tool A over project management
tool B, that sounds great.

They all work.  MICHAEL LEPECH: What
I've told our teams,

does our organization have an
institutional license for one of them, because we'll
probably just end up using it? ANAND SUBRAMANI: Is it free?

Or can you use
somebody else's seats? That's all true. But again, going back
to a point from earlier

is-- and I'm not suggesting
that the value of these things is zero. But if you're spending hours and
hours talking about which thing

you should use, that time is
probably better spent elsewhere. MICHAEL LEPECH: Yeah,
totally, totally.

So yeah, we've been hitting
some of the questions, loving the questions coming
in the chats and in the Q&A.

So keep those coming. So I want to shift the
discussion now from, OK,

is it dead and how
has it changed? to how do we stay relevant
as product managers?

And of course, the elephant
in the room here is GenAI.

And how generative AI
is changing the role?

And so in order
to stay relevant, how do we best harness AI
in our day-to-day work?

ANAND SUBRAMANI: Yeah. I'll do a little bit
of a side plug first, and then I'll come back to this. If you haven't used a
bunch of the AI tools

and you're relying on news or
LinkedIn or whatever to tell you what's good, I very
strongly suggest

getting first-hand
experience with them. And there's two
reasons for this. One of them is
it's always better to form your own opinions
than getting somebody else's

filtered opinions. But the second is they're
changing very rapidly, including for whatever your
particular use case is.

So OCR wasn't very
good six months ago. Now it's really good,
whatever it happens to be. So there's no substitute
for doing it yourself

and being on the cutting-edge. I'm not advocating anyone tool. Pick anything you want. But just a piece of advice
that actually had all product

managers on my
team do is you need to be using them so you
know what they're good at. Don't rely on the
CNBC article you

read about how AI is going
to kill product management. So that out of the way, how
is it going to change it?

I think it's going to
change a couple of things. So I'd like to break
this question down into how it impacts engineering
and how it impacts product

and design, separately,
because I think the answers are different. In terms of how it impacts
product and design,

what I have seen
it be very good at is dramatically reduce the time
to a first working prototype.

What I mean by
that is previously, where somebody might
be getting into Figma or Sketch or
Photoshop or whatever,

and drawing a bunch
of mocks, AI is now very quick at getting
something working.

But the important point
here is "kind of." It's very good at
the 80%, and it's very bad at the remaining 20%.

One of my favorite
descriptions of AI tools was it's like having
infinite interns. I'm like, yeah,
that's kind of right.

So it'll get you the first 80%
but it get you the last 20%. But what that does
is it actually splits apart what was previously
a learning cycle and a work

cycle. Where previously, if I wanted
to put a prototype in front of someone, I had
to make a hypothesis and then do a bunch of work to
actually implement something

that could test the hypothesis. The second one is now collapsed
to not zero, but close to zero.

So the job as a product manager
is more important than ever. You still have to have
the right hypotheses, but the cycle time on
getting the thing right

should be much lower
than it was in the past. And that is a very
powerful skill, because now you can put
six working prototypes

in front of someone instead
of one set of screenshots.

I find that to be very
powerful on the PM side. But again, it won't do
the last 20% for you.

So it's not a substitute
for actually making it. MICHAEL LEPECH: If I think about
our Double Diamond framework,

we used to spend-- and for those
that aren't familiar with it, it breaks the product
management role down

into a problem-focused
set of activities, followed by a solution-focused
set of activities.

And the generative AI
piece doesn't necessarily help you, to a large extent,
with the problem-focused piece,

because there, you still
have to talk to customers. You still have to
understand problems. You still need really
deep, empathetic learning.

But that solution-oriented
space, which, as you said, used to take us a lot more
time and a lot more effort,

we can now get reasonably
working minimum lovable type

product ideas out
in front of folks and iterate on that Double
Diamond so much quicker and so

much cheaper than
we could before. And so where I see
the real benefit is it's going to result
in better products

because we are able to
get more options out in front of that
customer for them to react to and tell
us what they like,

because customers,
very often, don't know exactly what it is they like. But when they see it,
they definitely know it.

And on the converse
side, if they see something they don't like,
they definitely know that, too. ANAND SUBRAMANI:
Definitely agree with that.

And that's a nice segue
to the second part, which is how it changes engineering. What I've seen on
engineering is it

is a pretty good amplifier on
engineering team productivity. If you made me
guess right now, I'd

guess it makes you somewhere
between 20% and a third faster if you're
really good at it. Most teams aren't
really paying attention.

Almost everyone is lagging here. For example, I spent
the last week playing with Cursor, which
is an AI tool.

It is stunningly
good at writing code. Things that used to
take me hours to write, I can literally write
in 10 seconds now.

So I think that people
have not caught up to the state of
the art, and it's going to take a
while for this stuff

to percolate through
engineering organizations. But once you figure out what you
want from the prototype phase and you need to build it
properly to 100% level,

I still think AI has
a role to play here. And it's hard to predict
the end game here because it's hard to predict
the end game of exponentials

in general. But right now, it might make
you, let's say, a third faster. So your engineering
team should definitely

be using a bunch of AI tools,
whether it's Cursor or GitHub, Copilot or whatever,
because they are very good.

MICHAEL LEPECH: And I
think that's exactly right.

When we talk about the
application of GenAI, specifically within the
product management role,

we try to think a lot about
not replacing your team, but augmenting your team,
because, as you noted,

it'll get you 80% of the
way there on some things, but that 20% is still going
to be super, super critical.

And so how do you see,
as a product manager, on your team, the intersection
of GenAI with your own skills

and with your own
abilities at innovating in certain ways and those
skills on your team? How do you use this
to best augment?

ANAND SUBRAMANI: Yeah. I do think in the medium term,
for anybody who adopts these, either the teams will be smaller
or the productivity will go up.

And your company has to decide
which one they care about. Like, is it better for you to
test the same number of things

with 70% as many
people, or to test-- I can't do the fast
math-- but 40% more things with the same number of people?

That is a strategy
question, and an org design question that will differ on
every company and your cash

position and a bunch
of other things. But I think from a product
management perspective,

what it'll do is
it will hopefully-- to one of the
questions earlier-- will hopefully push
the roll even further into the problem space.

Where they're like, look,
the project management stuff gets easier, the
execution gets easier, the complexity and all
that stuff goes down.

what really matters is, are
you making the right bets, and do you have the
right hypotheses? So I hope that it nudges product
management even more squarely

and away from project
management, and more into the understand your customer piece.

And to give you a sense of
things that are possible-- again, I just happen to have
been working with Cursor

this week-- they're doing
$100 million in revenue with 30 people. That was impossible
five years ago.

So I do think you'll see more
and more companies getting built that just have
fewer people in them,

but it doesn't make the
role less important. It just means you probably
don't need 10 of them. MICHAEL LEPECH: Yeah,
so just last month,

we had, as part of STVP's
ongoing series on mental health

and well-being of founders. We had Reid Hoffman
on campus speaking, and he was talking about
his new book, SuperAgency.

And I thought it was a
wonderful discussion around how AI and large language models
can be used to give us

all super agency, meaning super
powers and super capabilities that we have never had before.

And he commented
on, we'll really know this is the case when
you get your first unicorn valuation for a single founder
with a single employee,

all leveraging all of that. ANAND SUBRAMANI:
And we're close. We're getting it with
20, but we're not

getting it with one yet. Yeah. The caution I would have
on generative AI tools

is to some-- if you look under
the hood of how LLMs work, fundamentally next
word predictors, they're the average
of the internet.

You're not going to get
amazing company strategy from the average
of the internet. So there are things
that it's good at, and there are things
that it's bad at.

If you want to figure
out how to write code that OAuths to
Google, though, you're going to get amazing
answers from the average

of the internet. So knowing where to use it
and where to not use it also is super important. And I think you can't really
delegate customer understanding

to it, nor can you delegate
company strategy to it. But it's very good at getting
delegated implementation.

MICHAEL LEPECH: Yeah,
in the chat right now, we're getting a bunch
of folks coming in saying, yes, they've used it
for rapid prototyping,

super fast visualizations,
reduced cycle times, all great stuff.

So wonderful to see
those things in the chat. In light of all
of that, what are

employer is looking
for in their PMs now? If you're going
out there looking

for a job in product
management-- we have a couple questions with people coming
from different engineering

backgrounds, technical
backgrounds, who want to maybe break
in to the PM role,
